msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to Sophia Scott Lockhart, , May 15h. 1836

div.p:
There is no help for it my dear
Mrs Lockhart I must torment
you - and you must torment
Mr Lockhart for me - about this
poor Mrs. Carmichael. She writes
to me with such resigned humility
bout the Mss. Manuscripts which was put into
your great Apollo's hands for her
some half a year ago that I cannot
forbear plaguing you - All she
wants is a Verdict poor creature
let her know in one word whether
should do or not -
Mr Lockhart said
he would recommend to Murray
to publish if it would do - If it will
not she humbly prays to have the
Mss. Manuscripts back again and she will
not go on with it - She has written
one volume more and did intend
it encouraged to have finished the
work these June holidays ensuing
- She works as a schoolmistress 14 hours
a day & in her holidays she writes - poor

devoted creature - Pray rummage
over Lockharts mountains of
papers which I have this instant
in my minds eye! all pele mele!
And rummage over his mind
also till you draw out his opinion
- put it in what words you will to
me - even if it be only yes or no
I will convey it with all kindness.
or with all joy to the poor mother
& authoress - If the Mss. Manuscripts is to be
returned & it is not outrageously
large frank it to me by means
of Lord Glenelg Colonial Secy
When most obliging in doing such
jobs for me - Long life to Jobbing
& Jobbers - I remember your
dear father's saying to me apropos
to a franking job Croker did for
us "Croker has too good an Irish
"heart not to be ready to do a good
"job for a friend" -

I am sure Miss Martineau
would tear me to pieces to cry
tatters for such an antipolitical

justice phrase even uttered half in jest
and moreover would excommu
=nicate excommunicate me perhaps for feeling
pity for a poor hardworking
mother of a family whose works
I am well aware ought to
be judged only according to
their intrinsic merit and
exact value in the literary
market & compared with her
literary competitors - But sym-
pathy sympathy & compassion were put in
to the human heart luckily
long before Miss Martineau began to
write and she will never write
them out & would not mend
human society or increase the
sum of human happiness if
she did succeed in her
anti=chari
ty anti-charity crusade - I am quite sure
your Mr Lockhart thinks as I
do and has a soft place in his
heart which time & the world can-
not cannot harden - Sir Walter Scott let
me into that secret about him
long ago - and I hope my dear
Mrs L you will profit by it for me

for poor Mrs. Carmichael
Thank you for the message
you sent me by Harriet Butler
who faithfully delivered it - Rack
your brains till you recollect Ma'am
what it was. It was about some-
body somebody & something very interesting
That warmhearted Harriet sends
her Sons love to you; and her
her husband desires to add as
much of his as is decent -
Pray tell me whether you are
well and happy - (You including
your husband and children)
- for believe me my dear Mrs.
Lockhart I have the most sin-
cere sincere affection & I will say fond-
ness fondness for your & Your conversation
& manners & disposition are
so suited to me - they have left
an impression on my mind
which can never wear out -
div.closer:
Even if we never meet again as
long as I last this will last - I
will ever be Yours affectionately
Maria Edgeworth

postscript.p:
If Mrs. Carmichaels
Mss
Manuscripts is too bulky to be
sent by Lord Glenelgs frank send it to my sister
1 North Audley Street - write to medirectly at all
events through T.S. Drummond Dublin Castle
